Award.AwardTitle: Bottom-up Synthesis of Nanocrystalline Intermetallic Coatings with Controlled Microstructures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Coatings made of metallic alloys are used in a wide range of industries from machine tools to automobiles, aircraft and thermal power plants. These coatings increase resistance to wear, corrosion and oxidation and enhance the performance of structural and functional components to which they are applied. Thus, the ability to tailor the properties of metallic alloy coatings would lead to significant improvements in the efficiency and lifetime of automobile and aircraft engines, cutting tools and power plant turbines and tubings. This award supports fundamental research that aims to control the microstructure (size, shape and distribution of small-scale crystallites) of metallic alloy coatings. Since the mechanical, chemical and thermal properties are intimately connected to the microstructure, this would allow the PIs to tune the properties of the coatings for various applications. The research activity is integrated with education and outreach efforts that include a mentoring program for undergraduates, scientific demonstrations for high school students and training of graduate students in materials synthesis and characterization.

Current methods to synthesize metallic alloy coatings using either chemical or physical deposition processes provide only limited capability for controlling the microstructure. This project aims to develop a new bottom-up process to synthesize intermetallic coatings with tailored microstructures using physical vapor deposition. The central hypothesis of the project is that by methodically seeding nanocrystals during the growth process, amorphous intermetallic coatings can be controllably crystallized during subsequent annealing at the appropriate temperature. The project will elucidate the fundamental physics of this process and demonstrate its practical viability by synthesizing and characterizing nanostructured titanium aluminide (TiAl) coatings with controlled grain size, aspect ratio and spatial distribution. In addition, microstructural evolution, stability and mechanical behavior of the synthesized TiAl coatings will be investigated using in situ transmission electron microscopy and X-ray diffraction experiments to understand the crystallization kinetics and structure-property relationships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of the project was to develop a new method to synthesize intermetallic thin films/coatings with highly controlled microstructures. The research conducted in this project has shown that

1. The crystallization of amorphous precursor films can be controlled by systematically seeding nanocrystals into the precursor films.

2. By altering the spatial distribution of the seed crystals, the grain size, aspect ratio and grain size distribution of the films can be explicitly controlled.

3. The crystallization temperature of the amorphous precursor films can be significantly reduced by choosing appropriate seed crystals.

4. The seed crystals act as preferential grain nucleation sites during thermally induced crystallization of the amorphous films, as revealed by in situ transmission electron microscopy annealing experiments.

5. The nanocrystalline and ultrafine-grained NiTi films synthesized using this method show an unusual combination of pseudoelastic and shape memory effect.

These findings have been disseminated to the research community through journal publications and conference presentations. A provisional patent application has also been filed.

The project has had a substantial impact in terms of human capital development by supporting the PhD thesis of two students. During the course of the project, the students developed skills related to thin film deposition and characterization, microfabrication, in situ materials testing and data analysis. One of the students is now employed as a research and development engineer in a major semiconductor manufacturing firm. The other student will soon be defending his PhD thesis and has accepted a research and development position in the semiconductor industry.

The education and outreach activities enabled by the project introduced more than 400 high school students and 50 first-year engineering students at Arizona State University to microscale materials testing and mechanical behavior of materials.


Last Modified: 09/11/2020
Modified by: Jagannathan Rajagopalan

The crystallization temperature of the amorphous precursor films can be significantly reduced by choosing appropriate seed crystals. 4. The seed crystals act as preferential grain nucleation sites during thermally induced crystallization of the amorphous films, as revealed by in situ transmission electron microscopy annealing experiments. 5. The nanocrystalline and ultrafine-grained NiTi films synthesized using this method show an unusual combination of pseudoelastic and shape memory effect. These findings have been disseminated to the research community through journal publications and conference presentations. A provisional patent application has also been filed. The project has had a substantial impact in terms of human capital development by supporting the PhD thesis of two students. During the course of the project, the students developed skills related to thin film deposition and characterization, microfabrication, in situ materials testing and data analysis.
